title: Big Data Analytics - Overview
summary: This document provides an overview of big data analytics, including the challenges of dealing with large amounts of unstructured data and the process of collecting, munging, and delivering data products useful to organizations. The CRISP-DM methodology is also discussed as a framework for organizing the work needed by an organization to deliver clear insights from big data.
content_preview:
Big Data Analytics - Overview 
The volume of data that one has to deal has exploded to unimaginable levels in the past decade, 
and at the same time, the price of data storage has systematically reduced. Private companies and 
research institutions capture terabytes of data about their users’ interactions, business, social 
media, and also sensors from devices such as mobile phones and automobiles. The challenge of 
this era is to make sense of this sea of data. This is where big data analytics ...

title:
Risk Practice 
Building the  
internal-audit function 
of the future
summary: The internal audit function of the future must adapt to new risks and challenges in a dynamic risk landscape. The pandemic has led to increased asset risks, uncertainty around reputations and sustainability, and a need for greater agility in IA functions. To address these challenges, decision makers may focus on three areas: recognizing new risks, aligning capabilities with emerging risks, and reviewing current operations to ensure they are equipped for the future.

title: Artificial intelligence: A definition
summary: This document provides an overview of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML), including their definitions, categories, and applications. It also discusses the importance of understanding AI and ML for business executives. The document mentions various types of ML algorithms, including supervised learning, reinforcement learning, and unsupervised learning. Additionally, it provides examples of how ML can be used in different industries.
content_preview:
1
Artificial intelligence: A definition
AI is typically defined as the ability of a machine to perform cognitive functions we associate with human minds, such 
as perceiving, reasoning, learning, and problem solving. Examples of technologies that enable AI to solve business 
problems are robotics and autonomous vehicles, computer vision, language, virtual agents, and machine learning.
Machine learning: A definition
Most recent advances in AI have been achieved by applying machine learning to ver...

summary: Document discussing ai governance topics with focus on data, science, statistics.
content_preview:
50 years of Data Science
David Donoho
Sept. 18, 2015
Version 1.00
Abstract
More than 50 years ago, John Tukey called for a reformation of academic statistics. In ‘The
Future of Data Analysis’, he pointed to the existence of an as-yet unrecognized science, whose
subject of interest was learning from data, or ‘data analysis’. Ten to twenty years ago, John
Chambers, Bill Cleveland and Leo Breiman independently once again urged academic statistics
to expand its boundaries beyond the classical domain...

title: Artificial intelligence: Transforming the future of banking
summary: This document discusses the potential of artificial intelligence (AI) in transforming the future of banking. It highlights the importance of AI in banking, the challenges of implementing AI systems, and the need for banks to invest in personalized services to retain customer trust and loyalty. The article also provides examples of how banks have used data-driven AI to offer personalized reward programs and predict customers' needs proactively.

title:
table formed by counting of the number of the four
outcomes of a binary classifier
summary: A confusion matrix is a table formed by counting the number of outcomes of a binary classifier, with various measures derived from it including error rate, accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, precision, and false positive rate. The best measures are 0.0 for all and the worst are 1.0 for all.
content_preview:
A confusion matrix of binary classification is a two by two
table formed by counting of the number of the four
outcomes of a binary classifier
Various measures can be derived from a confusion matrix
(refer next slide)
We usually denote them as TP, FP, TN, and FN instead of
“the number of true positives”, and so on
Binary Classification Confusion Matrix Error rate (ERR) is calculated as the number of all incorrect
predictions divided by the total number of the dataset. The
best error rate is 0.0...

title: a causal evidence that AI faculty departures from universities reduced the creation of
summary: This academic document analyzes the impact of AI faculty departures from universities on innovation. The authors provide a causal evidence that the departure of AI professors from universities reduced the creation of startups by students who then graduated from these universities, as well as the early-stage funding these startups receive. They also highlight the disruption in the knowledge transfer from professors to students as the main channel for the negative effect on innovation.
category: Machine Learning, Deep Learning, NLP, Computer Vision, Data Science, AI Governance, AI Ethics
content_preview:
Artiﬁcial Intelligence, Human Capital, and
Innovation∗
Michael Gofman1 and Zhao Jin2
August 20, 2019
Abstract
Human capital is essential to AI-driven innovation. The scarcity of the human cap-
ital needed for AI R&D created an unprecedented brain drain of AI professors from
North American universities into the industry between 2004 and 2018. We provide
a causal evidence that AI faculty departures from universities reduced the creation of
startups by students who then graduated from these univers...

summary: This lecture focuses on algorithms for reinforcement learning, which is a learning paradigm that involves controlling a system to maximize a long-term objective. title: Beyond Capacity Management: How Health Systems Can Ensure Value for Money in Addressing the Elective Surgical Care Backlog Created by COVID-19
summary: This paper discusses the elective surgical care backlog created by COVID-19 and presents a framework for policy makers to address it. The authors propose five levers to address the backlog: optimize, extend, expand, coordinate, and reconfigure. They also present key considerations and provide country case studies to illustrate their approach.
content_preview:

title: Big Data Analytics - Overview
summary: The document discusses big data analytics and its importance in today's era of vast amounts of data. It describes the big data analytics life cycle, which includes collecting data from various sources, munging it, and delivering data products useful to organizations.
content_preview:
Big Data Analytics - Overview 
The volume of data that one has to deal has exploded to unimaginable levels in the past decade, 
and at the same time, the price of data storage has systematically reduced. Private companies and 
research institutions capture terabytes of data about their users’ interactions, business, social 
media, and also sensors from devices such as mobile phones and automobiles. The challenge of 
this era is to make sense of this sea of data. This is where big data analytics ...

title:
The goal is to create a model that predicts the
value of a target variable by learning simple
summary: Decision Trees (DTs) are a supervised learning method used for classification and regression. They aim to create a model that predicts the value of a target variable by learning simple decision rules from the data features. DTs have advantages such as simplicity, interpretability, and ability to handle both numerical and categorical data. However, they also have limitations such as overfitting, instability, and difficulty in handling certain concepts.
content_preview:
Decision Trees (DTs) are a non-parametric supervised
learning method used for classification and regression.
The goal is to create a model that predicts the
value of a target variable by learning simple
decision rules inferred from the data features.
A tree can be seen as a piecewise
constant approximation.
